text:
I have about 2 yrs experience of content writing and basic SEO skills. What would you recommend a good way to go about writing for a startup or venture capital firm since they are of interest to me. Till now my only successes have been
1. Cold Emails with a small pitch
2. Linkedin Requests
3. Facebook and Slack Groups

Any advice would be appreciated :)

elements.text:

text: If you're the sole leader in the content space at Automate and there isn't an established trajetory, shoot for the moon! :slightly_smiling_face: Do look at titles and growth paths on the product and success sides of the company and go from there.

elements.text: If you're the sole leader in the content space at Automate and there isn't an established trajetory, shoot for the moon!
Do look at titles and growth paths on the product and success sides of the company and go from there.

text: I dont have an advice but I’d like to ask you about these three methods. What did you do exactly in each case?

elements.text: I dont have an advice but I’d like to ask you about these three methods. What did you do exactly in each case?

text: Hi Alastair! I had success expanding my writing opportunities and portfolio by partnering with local creative talent/sourcing firms. I've worked with Aquent/Vitamin T (I think Vitamin T is their local brand to Indianapolis): <https://aquentstudios.com/>. There are a couple of other local creative firms I worked with, and they were really responsive. It was kind of feast or famine. Once I submitted my portfolio and made myself available for writing projects, I'd go months without hearing from them, but then it would seem they had 2-3 jobs available over the course of a few months.

attachments.title: Home - Aquent Studios
attachments.text: Let our talented team transform your strategic objectives into creative deliverables that engage, persuade, and inspire your audience to act.

elements.text: Hi Alastair! I had success expanding my writing opportunities and portfolio by partnering with local creative talent/sourcing firms. I've worked with Aquent/Vitamin T (I think Vitamin T is their local brand to Indianapolis):

. There are a couple of other local creative firms I worked with, and they were really responsive. It was kind of feast or famine. Once I submitted my portfolio and made myself available for writing projects, I'd go months without hearing from them, but then it would seem they had 2-3 jobs available over the course of a few months.

text: Sounds like you’ve done okay so far! Are you picking a specific niche of startups to work with? And are you “just a writer for hire” or are you positioning yourself as an expert in a particular vertical ?

elements.text: Sounds like you’ve done okay so far! Are you picking a specific niche of startups to work with? And are you “just a writer for hire” or are you positioning yourself as an expert in a particular vertical ?

text:
Hello all,

Okay so this is why I sought out (and found) a wonderful community like this one :hearts:

*I am on the fence as to whether I should start looking for what's next, or to stay where I am.*

My argument for staying is that I really like my coworkers, I have never been in a workplace that listened to my input and valued it so much. Plus, they responded to the coronavirus crisis rwally well and I am setup to work from home (possibly even staying remote).

My feelings about leaving centre around a crushed dream. I was on a mission to grow my own team, and build out my own service at our agency. I saw a path to management and to leading something that I built. It's why I've been working so hard this past year. My colleagues were supportive of this, but now I have a new manager and he has told me that is extremely unlikely, basically not going to happen.

And so I've lost my motivation. I have no interest in doing a 9-5 just to do it. If I don't have a path to growing my career here, I feel like it's time to consider alternatives.

*What would you suggest?*

TL:DR My dream of career growth within my current role is dead. I am seriously demotivated and bored now.

Thanks for reading :pray:

text:
A bit more on the manager: he is in charge of revenue growth for the agency and he basically said that my soft skill service doesn't sell easily and we need to focus on staying afloat as the recession hits.

So he's not wrong, but he didn't know just how much that the idea of building out my own team was motivating me to be working as hard as I have.

elements.text:

text: Hi Eliot, thanks for putting out this question. It's a decision I've been pondering about for the past weeks for different reasons though. More than being able to give you proper advice I'd love to share the questions I'm asking myself: Is the frustration/slump in motivation temporary and is it possible I will find somehting else to focus my energy on in this workplace that will keep me going long-term? If the answer is "no": What really keeps me here? What would a new role need to look like so I'm willing to trade the security of my current employment for the uncertainty of new possibilities?

elements.text: Hi Eliot, thanks for putting out this question. It's a decision I've been pondering about for the past weeks for different reasons though. text: The good thing about your situation seems to be that generally speaking you're in a positive environment which means you don't have the pressure to get out of there immediately. So you don't need to take a rushed decision but can focus on finding something sustainable for yourself.
